title: Question: why does “science” use the term “random” — a philosophic description — for “unknown” — a more mathematical term? Random number generators do not act randomly, but logically. - Quora

response.answer_text: Science uses the word “random” to mean different things… and not just in the philosophical sense. You will be familiar with the way words can have more than one use? That is just how language works. This is the answer to the question:” “because words don’t work the way the question assumes they do.” However, that does not get you very far… I’ll explain: Something being random is not the same as something being “unknown”… and that is not the use of the term in philosophy either. Chance versus Randomness The question mentions random-number generators … which generate “pseudo-random” numbers, not random numbers … so the term “random number generator” is a misnomer. It is used because everyone understands that the object of such systems is to approximate as closely as needed, a random process. It need only have very low predicability for the period of the simulation. There are, however, random-number generators that do not behave logically … because they use natural processes rather than computer logic. For instance, a meteorological station measuring wind-speed in a gusty area is staggeringly random, if the number is the lowest digit of the speed most recently recorded when accessed. You are defied to find the pattern. In scientific theories, “random” processes are a mathematical idealization. We accept that we cannot get to absolute random like we cannot get to infinity, or any absolute value or quality. That does not stop the concepts being useful for making models.

In a mathematical context, “random” is not a philosophical term, and it has a much stricter meaning than simply “unknown.” It’s a probabilistic term, and it means that all numbers are equally likely, and that the probability of any number at any time does not depend on what numbers turned up before. Of course a programmed “random number generator” is not truly random, but every number has almost the same probability, and the probability distribution at any time depends significantly only on occurrences in the remote past. That makes it useful for experimental models. Question: why does “science” use the term “random” — a philosophic description — for “unknown” — a more mathematical term? Random number generators do not act randomly, but logically.

Question: why does “science” use the term “random” — a philosophic description — for “unknown” — a more mathematical term? Because statistics, a field of mathematics, uses the term random. Also, “unknown”implies that nothing is known about the event, while random processes usually follow a predictable mathematically defined distribution - Gaussian, chi-squared, or whatever. Random number generators do not act randomly, but logically. If they’re behaving “logically” because they’re driven by an algorithm, they’re actually pseudo-random number generators. However, over the past few decades it has become common for CPUs to include a hardware-based random bit generator which uses thermal noise across a diode or other similar quantum mechanical source as a source of randomness.

Question: why does “science” use the term “random” — a philosophic description — for “unknown” — a more mathematical term? Answer: Because certain quantum phenomena seem to have what’s technically called ‘No hidden variables’ i.e. Nothing at all ‘behind the scenes’ (at least as far as anyone can tell). Random number generators do not act randomly, but logically. No unless they are driven by some quantum phenomena like the decay of a radioactive element which seems to be without any ‘hidden variables’ behind the scenes but pseudo-random number generators are just as good if there’s no way to predict their deterministic results. They are fine for something like creating a lottery number draw where balls bounce all over the place & cannot be controlled or predicted even though in principle they could be but not in practice.

Basically random has two different meanings: Not deliberately selected for a purpose. This is the philosophical and linguistical meaning.Not accurately determined by the cause. This is the scientific meaning describing the outcome of probabilistic events.There is a third one, but that applies only to mathematical series (plural). Mathematical randomness means lack of pattern and predictability in a series of numbers.

Von Neumann is quoted as saying, “Anyone who attempts to generate random numbers by deterministic means is, of course, living in a state of sin.” I think it’s generally understood in science and mathematics that these are not random numbers, which is why they are called pseudo-random. I don’t know the history of the terms, but “random” has been used for a variable ranging over a probability space for a long time in mathematics. “Unknown” doesn’t seem to imply that a probability is involved, nor even that it is impossible to prove what the value is from already known facts. So I think people would tend to avoid using it in the same contexts for lack of specificity.
Your question is nonsense. Science does not use “random” for “unknown”, and the opposite of “random” is not “logical".
